transcripts.text: Thank you.  Thank you.  Thank you.  Thank you.  We're back with Wayne Angel, Bob McTeer, Brian Westbury, Peter Schiff, and waiting in the wings, Steve Leisman and Rick Santelli.  Mr.  Santelli today gasped on the trading floor as the dollar hemorrhaged against the euro as the Fed came in with its most dramatic pump priming probably since, I don't know when, the middle 1930s.  Peter, I want to go to you, Peter Schiff.  You used to have a saying in the trading room of the big firm I used to work for.  I might add that firm is no longer in business.  This was many years ago.  I used to call it palm trees growing on the trading floor as the Fed was pumping out large quantities.  quantities of money.  And, Peter, I want you to respond to this, because I want to ask Wayne Angel, and I want to ask Bob McTeer, when the last time they went to Argentina, because that subject interests me a lot.  Meanwhile, on the full screen, we're going to put the Fed's balance sheet, reserve bank credit, we're going to put the monetary base, and we're going to put M1, just to let people see the degree to which we have expanded the money side.  Just throw it up there.  Reserve bank credit is over 100%.  Monetary basis, I think, even on a smooth basis, about 45%.  And M1 and M2 are both growing about 8%.  Peter Schiff, where is this going to lead?  Where?  Are we going to get economic recovery?  Are people going to buy mortgages?  What?

It's going to lead to disaster.  Now, you're right to bring up Argentina.  A lot of people bring up the example of Japan.  We're not going to follow in Japan's footsteps.  They're a wealthy creditor nation.  They have a high savings rate.  They had a trade surplus.  We're going to follow in the footsteps of Argentina.  So if you want to look at America's future, go look at Argentina's past.  This is what is going to happen.  All we're doing is creating money.  Asset bubbles have burst.  Real estate prices have to fall.  Companies have to fail.  This phony service sector economy has to be allowed to unwind.  We have to let the free market function.  If the government simply tries to manufacture savings out of thin air and get people to go deeper into debt to buy more products that we can't afford, they're going to destroy our currency.
Peter, why do you need an iPod?
Peter, why do you think that the distinguished, very distinguished Bob McTeer and the very distinguished Wayne Angel don't agree with you?  Where's the disagreement?

Look, they've been wrong for years.  You know, they didn't see this train wreck happening.  It was right in their face.  You know, I've seen this disaster.  I wrote a book about the coming economic collapse.  So they haven't understood these dynamics.
Let me get a response.  Let me get a response.  Wayne Angel, please respond to Peter Schiff.

Well, that's just sheer nonsense.  The fact of the matter is that we are not in 2002, but we in 2008, moving into 2009, we are in a serious global falling commodity price movement.  No, we're not.  In four months.  Well, we are.  And the Fed is taking the action it needs to take.  And Bernanke will not be a Greenspan who will leave the ease on too long.

How do you know that?  Bob McTeer, I want to ask you that.  This, in some sense, unwinding from this massive Fed intervention.  It's like unwinding from this massive TARP intervention.  The American government is now engaged and intervened in the U.S.  economy in ways nobody ever dreamed possible.  All right, Bob McTeer, you heard Peter.  How do you unwind?  How does the Fed unwind?  How do we unwind from this unprecedented government intervention?

You don't go immediately from money creation to inflation.  The money's got to get spent first, and nobody's spending any money.  Everybody's slowed down the velocity.  Everybody's hoarding.  The financial institutions are hoarding money.  And the Dallas Fed conducted two conferences in Buenos Aires.  I made a speech on the floor of the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, and I visited Evita at her grave.
Did that remind you of the current situation?  I'm delighted.  I used to spend some time in Buenos Aires, but it was when they were pegging to the U.S.  dollar and gold.  We're doing neither.

Larry, I think you have to give the Federal Reserve a little bit more credit for thinking about an exit strategy here.  Why?  Peter, just give me half a second here.  I'll be done.  There are several programs the Federal Reserve has put in place that basically unwind themselves, and they offer interest rates that are not competitive in a more normal market, but they are competitive and actually advantageous in this very frozen-up market.  Let me give you another example of the TARP here.  The TARP money is a dividend of 5% for five years.  that goes to 9% after the fifth year.  So there is an incentive there for a bank to come forward and take out the government in the fifth year.  There are several programs here that have embedded exit strategies.
Okay, that's an interesting point.  But Brian Westbury, I don't know about those incentives regarding commercial paper.
Five years is a long time.

These consumer loans, you know, they're going to buy the asset-backed consumer paper and so forth, the mortgage-backed paper.  I mean, Brian, I guess the basic question here this evening is, will this work?  Will this work?  Will this get the American economy growing next year without inflation?

My belief, my sincerest, deep down to the bottom of my heart belief is that mark-to-market accounting is killing us and that everything the government is doing is to try and offset the damage that mark-to-market accounting is doing.  They're injecting capital into financial institutions when mark-to-market accounting is erasing it.  They're buying assets.  They're pushing money to the Fed, expanding the balance sheet when private sector companies won't hold these assets because they're afraid they're going to get marked down.
But it's not the accounting that's bad.  It's the assets.
Peter, Peter.
I agree with Peter Schiff on this.
So I believe that mark-to-market accounting is killing us, and we're doing all of these things to try and get around it.
That's like blaming your fever on the thing.  thermometer.
I mean, the problem is the assets.
That is a terrible analogy.  It makes no sense whatsoever.  None whatsoever.
You think these assets are so valuable, you buy them.
Why would I buy them when they're going to get marked down in my face?
So the government intervention, there you go.  You just said it.  That's it.

The fact is that Brian said, why would I buy them when they're going to go lower?  Hence, the presence and the footprint and the shadow of the government keeps the vultures in the system for doing what it does best.

I just want to know, gentlemen, this is something that bothers me.  I have been a proponent of easier money up to a point.  Now, the Federal Reserve, which distinctly, clearly mentioned its own balance sheet, that's how they're going to operate.  It's sort of a Milton Friedman-like policy, expand the balance sheet, pump in a lot of new cash.  Look, gentlemen.  Wayne Angel, you first.  I want to get a whip around.  The Fed has expanded the balance sheet from 900 billion to 2.2 trillion.  They've done that in a couple of months.  They may go to 3.5 trillion.  When is enough enough, Wayne Angel?  When is enough enough?  Because I don't want Rick Santelli, who I dearly love, tomorrow to go down for the count if the dollar loses again against the euro.  I may lose the guy.  And this program and this network cannot afford to lose Santelli.  The states can't afford it.  The country cannot afford to lose Santelli if the dollar crashes again against the euro.  Wayne Angel, help me out.  How much do they have expanded their balance sheet?

We have never seen the kind of excess reserves in the system the Fed has in today.  But I just guarantee you that Chairman Bernanke is going to pull those back as soon as he sees the first signs of rising prices.
Hey, Larry, whip around.  Peter Schiff, real quick, and then Brian, and then Bob McTeer.  Real quick, whip around, fellas.  I'm out of time.

Yeah, the idea that they're going to be able to raise rates when they finally see inflation is nonsense.  If they won't raise them now, they'll never raise them.  The longer they wait, the harder it's going to get.  That's an important point.  They're just going to keep lying about it.
Brian Westbury, did Ben Bernanke sign on to Team Obama today, basically?  Is that what we saw?  Yeah, basically.

basically did.  But one thing to remember about this expansion in the balance sheet, it is not all printing money.  In some cases, they borrowed money from the Treasury and bought assets.  That just expands the balance sheet.  It's not printing money.  And when they take reserves from banks and buy commercial paper, that's not printing money either.
Bob McTeer, I need you to tell me, how are we going to unwind this unprecedented government intervention by the Fed?
First, let me say that Brian's absolutely right about mark to market.  And secondly, you keep priming the pump until some water starts coming out.
And what happens?
And then the ship sinks.
Yeah, that's, ooh.  We may have to end on that note.
Look, the economy is falling off a cliff.
Rick Santelli, I want you to give me the last word.
We don't need the Fed to push it.

I want to make sure Rick Santelli is still operating because, as I said before, the country cannot do without him.  But I worry if the dollar cracks up again against the euro.  Rick, you get the last word.

Well, I think that the dollar is going to have a heck of a time, and I think as good as that may be for exports, the real notion of a falling dollar and why it's good for exports is because the average American can't afford to buy what the rest of the world is selling at the same price due to its currency, and I think that's key.
And remember, all of this stimulus...
You can't eat an iPod, and I want to say that.
Rick drinks way too much French wine.  It's not an issue.  If you're not drinking French wine, domestic purchasing power of the dollar is stronger given declining inflation.
Not for long.
Go to California Wine, Rick.
You'll be in good shape.  Bob McCheer, Brian Westbury, Steve Leisman, Rick Santelli, Peter Schiff, you're going to serve a little more time in the stock market group.  Thank you very much.
Commence primary ignition.
What up?  Thank you.  Thank you.
Thank you.
